Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Synthesis of Hard Magnetic Nanoparticles and Fabrication of Micromagnets for Microelectromechanical System (MEMS) Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop anisotropic hard magnetic nanoparticles and nanoflakes based on rare-earth transition metal compounds, which can be agglomerated by screen printing and tape casting into micro- or sub-millimeter permanent magnet structures. The excellent magnetic properties, small size and particular morphology of the nanoparticles and nanoflakes will allow for high magnetic performance with dimensions that bridge the current gap between the permanent magnet thin films (about a few microns) and micromachined permanent magnets (typically larger than 500 microns). This project is expected to (1) synthesize permanent magnet nanoflakes and nanoparticles with magnetic properties comparable to those of the bulk counterparts, (2) prepare monolithic isotropic and anisotropic hard magnetic thick films by screen printing, (3) fabricate solitary isotropic and anisotropic hard magnetic thicker films or structures by tape casting, and (4) develop prototypes of sub-millimeter permanent magnet structures for terahertz (THz) devices and micro-undulators.

The broader/commercial impact of this project will be the potential to provide stable permanent magnet particles with submicron dimensions in large amount and with close-to-bulk magnetic properties, which will be an enabling technology for the $3.9 billion magnetic MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) market. The applications include micro-sensors, -motors, -generators, -undulators, high frequency (THz) vacuum electronic devices etc. The permanent magnet nanoflakes can also be used in anisotropic bonded magnets, which have many industrial applications with a market size of $434 million per year worldwide.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
A technology for producing film permanent magnets with different geometries by using micron and submicron powders, nanoparticles and nanoflakes, has been developed. The technology involves screen printing and tape casting, and the thickness of the films can vary from 40 to 100 microns while the lateral dimensions can vary from 0.04 inch to several inches.  This range covers the current dimensional gap between permanent magnet thin films (thickness of a few nanometers to a few microns) and micromachined permanent magnets (thickness of more than 500 microns). Moreover, the technology allows for intricate net micromagnet shapes by using a simple, low-cost method.  The project demonstrated that various types of permanent magnet materials, such as Sm-Co, Sm-Fe-N and Nd-Fe-B, can be reduced in size to micron, submicron and nano powders with quasi-spherical or nanoflake particle shape to be used for screen printed or tape casted magnet structures. The smaller the powder particle dimensions, the smaller the size and the better the shape control of the films. The powder and nanopowder / nanoflake particles behave like tiny permanent magnets, which are frozen in place by a binder optimized for film-type thicknesses. The developed technology allows also for particle alignment, which maximizes the total magnetic flux produced by these permanent magnet structures. These magnet films can have a density of magnetic energy of over 5 MGOe, which represents more than half of the value of bulk bonded high performance magnets with a thickness of at least 10 times larger. The permanent magnet films can be deposited on various substrates, flexible and non-flexible, metallic and non-metallic.  The permanent magnet structures developed during the course of this program, with thicknesses between tens of microns to hundred microns and lateral dimensions from 100 microns up, are suitable for applications such as micro-sensors, -motors, -generators, -undulators (accelerator based, non radioactive sources of X-rays and other radiation), high frequency (THz) vacuum electronic devices, etc., generically described as MEMS (Micro Electro-Mechanical Systems) or MAGMAS (MAGnetic Micro-Actuators and Systems). 


Last Modified: 11/29/2012
Modified by: Jinfang Liu

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A technology for producing film permanent magnets with different geometries by using micron and submicron powders, nanoparticles and nanoflakes, has been developed. The technology involves screen printing and tape casting, and the thickness of the films can vary from 40 to 100 microns while the lateral dimensions can vary from 0.04 inch to several inches. This range covers the current dimensional gap between permanent magnet thin films (thickness of a few nanometers to a few microns) and micromachined permanent magnets (thickness of more than 500 microns). Moreover, the technology allows for intricate net micromagnet shapes by using a simple, low-cost method. The project demonstrated that various types of permanent magnet materials, such as Sm-Co, Sm-Fe-N and Nd-Fe-B, can be reduced in size to micron, submicron and nano powders with quasi-spherical or nanoflake particle shape to be used for screen printed or tape casted magnet structures. The smaller the powder particle dimensions, the smaller the size and the better the shape control of the films. The powder and nanopowder / nanoflake particles behave like tiny permanent magnets, which are frozen in place by a binder optimized for film-type thicknesses. The developed technology allows also for particle alignment, which maximizes the total magnetic flux produced by these permanent magnet structures. These magnet films can have a density of magnetic energy of over 5 MGOe, which represents more than half of the value of bulk bonded high performance magnets with a thickness of at least 10 times larger. The permanent magnet films can be deposited on various substrates, flexible and non-flexible, metallic and non-metallic. The permanent magnet structures developed during the course of this program, with thicknesses between tens of microns to hundred microns and lateral dimensions from 100 microns up, are suitable for applications such as micro-sensors, -motors, -generators, -undulators (accelerator based, non radioactive sources of X-rays and other radiation), high frequency (THz) vacuum electronic devices, etc., generically described as MEMS (Micro Electro-Mechanical Systems) or MAGMAS (MAGnetic Micro-Actuators and Systems).
